content.webTitle: In praise of… Lewis and Harris | Editorial

fields.headline: In praise of… Lewis and Harris
fields.bodyText: Forget second-place Naxos. Ignore Capri, an also-ran. According to a TripAdvisor survey, Europe's best island is Lewis and Harris. Fifth best in the world, too, ahead of Easter Island and Ko Tao. And why not? The raw, wild beauty of Lewis and Harris is spectacular. Wild flowers stretch across the machair, golden eagles are a common sight overhead, and it is hard not to be moved by the prehistoric standing stones of Callanish. Perhaps the secret is that Lewis and Harris is not like any other part of Europe or even the UK. Strong, generous, often Gaelic-speaking communities survive there against the odds, with a fine natural diet, one of the healthiest in the western world. And nothing demonstrates the island's survival instinct better than the current Harris Tweed renaissance. When the late Donald Dewar asked an elderly woman in Uig on the west of Lewis if she felt remote, she floored him with her eloquent reply: "Remote from where?"
